week1.practice1_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening phase because the illness and recovery stress are ongoing. Right now, less than 5 hours of broken sleep is keeping your cortisol high at night, which delays stabilization. Locking in a steady sleep window is your â€œbig dominoâ€â€”it lowers those night spikes so your hair can move from shedding onset into stabilization more smoothly ğŸŒ™.

What to do

  • Choose a fixed bedtime and aim to be in bed within 30 minutes of it every night, weekend or not.
  • Set a consistent wake-up time anchored to morning light.
  • Give yourself at least an 8-hour sleep opportunity, even if your body only takes 6â€“7 at first.
  • Place your phone away from the bed to cut doom scrolling before sleep.

Your recommended schedule

  • Bedtime: 11:00â€“11:30 pm
  • Wake time: 7:00 am daily
  • Keep this window steady for 14 nights to let your circadian rhythm reset.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pick your wake-up anchor (7:00 am) and set an alarmâ€”even on weekends.
  2. Count back 8 hours to set your bedtime target (by 11 pm). Lights out within 30 min.
  3. Plan last screen use 30 mins before bed so doom scrolling doesnâ€™t push you past your window.
  4. If you wake in the night, avoid checking the clock; return to bed quietly.
  5. Stick with the anchors for 14 days before judging successâ€”your body lags a little behind the new consistency.

Why this works (for you)

  • Your COVID recovery still stresses the body; aligned sleep lowers night cortisol so fewer follicles flip into telogen.
  • Because your peak shedding likely began ~4â€“8 weeks after illness, steadier circadian rhythms shorten the time from worsening toward stabilization.
  • Regular hormones from consistent sleep support progesterone balance (helpful with your sometimes-PMS and irregular cycles).
  • This protocol makes sure regrowth gets the signal on schedule once illness stressors ease.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: If you still average under 5 hours of total sleep after 2 weeks, note it and consider extra support (from a sleep coach or medical provider).
  • Green lights: Waking at 7 am feels easier by week two; night wakings drop from 3 to 1â€“2; you notice less clumps on wash days.
  • Be gentleâ€”your body has been through illness. Even small wins (one extra hour of rest) are a step toward calmer scalp days â¤ï¸.
week1.practice2_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening windowâ€”right where fallout from your July over-exercise and September illness would naturally peak. The quickest lever for calming this phase is deeper, steadier sleep. Right now youâ€™re under 5h, with late caffeine and 2â€“3 awakenings. A windâ€‘down ritual is the â€œbig dominoâ€ that steadies cortisol, shortens the worst-shedding window, and sets you up for the stabilization phase and eventual regrowth âœ¨.

What to do

  • Set a 30â€‘min screenâ€‘off buffer (replace doomâ€‘scroll with paper, music, or gentle stretch).
  • Have your last light snack at least 1h before bed to ease digestion.
  • Do a 5â€‘min slow breathing or guided meditation to quiet rumination.
  • Create a â€œbridgeâ€ ritual (tea, journal, shower) that signals brain â†’ body: time to power down.

Your recommended schedule

  • Wake: 7:00 am fixed every day (anchor circadian rhythm).
  • Wind down: start 10:00 pm.
  • Lights out: 11:00 pm â†’ 7:00 am (target 8â€‘h window).

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Block calendar alarms at 10:00 pm: â€œStart windâ€‘down.â€
  2. Put phone in another room; keep one calming task ready (book, journal).
  3. Finish any food by 10:00 pm; sip only water or herbal tea before bed.
  4. Lie down by 11:00 pm; use slow breathing (4s in, 6s out) if racing thoughts start.
  5. Wake at 7:00 am even if sleep was shortâ€”consistency builds deeper nights later.

Why this works (for you)

  • Your illness trigger is still ongoing â†’ consistent sleep buffers the cortisol elevation that pushes more follicles into shedding.
  • Anchored wake + ritual speeds the shift from â€œworseningâ€ to â€œstabilization,â€ so you donâ€™t get stuck in a prolonged fallout loop.
  • Replacing doomâ€‘scrolling reduces lateâ€‘night blue light + stimulation that fragment deep sleep, the phase tied to repair and growth signals.
  • Longer consistent nights improve hormone rhythm (progesterone, thyroid) that support postâ€‘TE regrowth.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: If you still average <5h nightly after 2 weeks despite routine â†’ consider adding professional sleep support.
  • Green lights: Falling asleep faster (within ~20 min); fewer 2â€“3 am wakeâ€‘ups; slightly less hair left on pillow within 1â€“2 weeks.
  • Remember â¤ï¸: small shifts every night compoundâ€”this is you shortening the storm, not failing when a rough night happens.
week1.practice3_html:
```html

Toby, right now youâ€™re in the onset â†’ peak phase of shedding (illness ongoing, heavy loss >200). Your <5h sleep, late caffeine, and night wakings keep cortisol high at nightâ€”exactly when your follicles need repair signals. Creating a caffeine cutâ€‘off is a small lever that stabilizes your sleep curve so shedding can slow and you can move into stabilization on time ğŸŒ™.

What to do

  • Enjoy coffee/tea only before 1â€¯pm.
  • Switch to water, herbal tea, or decaf after lunch.
  • Pair your morning caffeine with protein (helps steadier energy, protects hair substrate).
  • Notice afternoons of energy dipsâ€”try sunlight or a short walk instead of a cup.

Your recommended schedule

  • Wake anchor: ~7:00 am daily (within 15 min).
  • Target windâ€‘down start: 10:00 pm.
  • Lights out: 11:00 pm â†’ aim for 7â€“8 h sleep window.
  • No caffeine past 1:00 pm (hard fence).

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set a daily alarm titled â€œLast Caffeineâ€ at 1â€¯pm as your reminder.
  2. Frontload your coffeeâ€”have your full serving with breakfast or lunch.
  3. When doomâ€‘scroll urges hit afternoon, swap with a 5â€‘min sunlight break outside.
  4. Keep herbal tea bags by your workspace for substitution rituals.
  5. Track your sleep: note whether your 2â€“3 night wakings reduce after a week.

Why this works (for you)

  • Late caffeine fragments sleep â†’ higher night cortisol. Cutting off by 1â€¯pm calms cortisol, which helps slow follicles exiting growth.
  • Your illness trigger (Sept) will likely show peak fallout in Octâ€“Nov. Better sleep now shortens and flattens this peak, speeding stabilization.
  • Your irregular cycles and low protein meals mean hormones/metabolism are under more pressure; deep sleep supports progesterone + thyroid tone, both linked to hair cycling.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Still <5h sleep after two weeks â†’ layer in windâ€‘down stack earlier; if severe, discuss with a professional.
  • Green lights: Fewer night wakings (maybe 1â€“2 instead of 3). Waking less wired. Slight shedding plateau within 2â€“3 weeks.
  • You donâ€™t need to be perfect. Every afternoon cup you skip is one win for your follicles â¤ï¸.
```
